content: I've changed "len" to "length" in the case names to avoid giving away a potential hint.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment:

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Well done :)
Nice problem! Really enjoyed it :)

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy to be understood, to be coded in few minutes. Perfect for a CoC !
Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hollerith_constant
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Constraints section
* To be more precise, the first constraint may be rewritten as e.g.

Every letter in [[s]] is in uppercase.
or
Every character in [[s]] is a space character or a letter in the alphabet and in uppercase.

Thanks.
Removed reverse mode, added an example to the statement and remove the wikipedia reference since somehow it was confusing for some people.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

The problem is good, and being a recognized one as Wikipedia covers it adds more value to the intent. But I won't be very happy to see such a problem in 'Reverse' mode where I just see these initial examples and have to figure out the requirement. Try helping with better examples in reverse mode or let me know if the initial 3-4 examples are not always shown in Reverse mode where we just have some public example testcases to figure out what's needed.
Rest seems good to me!
Update: Under the given Test cases (which are available during the challenge), and nice hidden validators, I have had a change of mind and see no problem in this under Reverse mode of Clash of Code as well.
I like the problem, but for a CoC, you can't expect someone to go to an external reference. Find a way to make the problem statement clearer so you don't need the external link.

The reference is just there if someone wants to know more, the statement is self-sufficient. I even think it's doable in reverse and as such it's on the possible modes.

What part of the statement did you not find clear enough?

Thanks for taking that to consideration. ðŸ˜€
Now that I think of it, I think having a sequel of it as a separate problem in itself (if does not exist here already) by swapping desired inputs and outputs of this one can be a good exercise in itself. Thoughts?
You are right, I'll go with the second one, I think it's a bit clearer. Thanks!

The reverse seems quite easier in comparison. It is just one line in python:

print("".join(chunk[2:] for chunk in hol[1:-1].split(",")))

It is not a bad idea but I will need to add explanations plus some input line for code/decode or sth. Since I think the clash is already fine in terms of difficulty I won't do it, but ofc if someone wants to write a similar clash they can.

Well, yes, actually reverse isn't really that hard to figure out, now that I think of it. Initially, for some reason it did seem daunting to me and I commented to suggest not to keep this problem in reverse mode without better testcases. Now that I look into it again after CodinGamin' for 2 more months from that comment, I now think that it may fit in reverse mode too quite well. I apologize now for that removal request, and would like to see it back in reverse mode as well. ðŸ˜Š

It's fine, many other people may find themselves in the same position that you were 2 months ago and think that the reverse mode in this clash is too difficult or unclear for them. 
There's many other nice reverse clashes, so it really doesn't matter if this one remains only for shortest/fastest. At any rate, thanks for your feedback.

could you add the reference back in the comments at least? >_>

EDIT: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hollerith_constant
Sure thing, I'll comment at the top and add it to the solution. I'd rather have it in the statement but there's always at least one person that complains about it (zzz).
